Questions: A 7-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician’s office for a follow-up visit. He was diagnosed with asthma when he was 3 years old and has since been on treatment for the condition. The appropriate mediators involved in the process are cytokines, such as interleukin-4 (IL-4) and interleukin-13 (IL-13). These cytokines stimulate B cells to switch from producing IgM and IgG antibodies to producing IgE antibodies, which are responsible for triggering allergic reactions. The experimental therapy aims to reduce the activity of these cytokines, thereby reducing the exaggerated response observed during the patient's asthmatic attacks, even when exposed to an allergen.
Option 2: Class switching is a process by which activated B cells change their antibody production from one isotype to another, for example, from IgM to IgG. This process is mediated by cytokines, which are signaling molecules that help coordinate the immune response. In the case of allergic asthma, cytokines such as interleukin-4 (IL-4) and interleukin-13 (IL-13) play a key role in class switching. These cytokines are produced by T cells and other immune cells and promote the production of IgE antibodies, which are responsible for triggering allergic reactions. In the experimental therapy being considered for the patient, the targeted mediator is likely IL-4 and/or IL-13. By reducing the activity of these cytokines, the therapy aims to reduce the production of IgE antibodies and thereby reduce the exaggerated response observed during asthmatic attacks, even when exposed to allergens.

Questions: A 47-year-old executive schedules an appointment his physician for a routine medical check-up.
